metadata.document_name: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT
metadata.source_pdf: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the main legal issues extracted from the document:
* The plaintiff's trademark registration is valid and subsistent.
* The plaintiff has established goodwill in its brand/trade mark "PRESTIGE" over the years.
* The defendant's use of the word "Prestige" for their products may be considered as passing off.
* Whether the defendant's trademark application dated 2nd November, 2018 is bona fide or not.
* Whether the defendant has any rights to use the word "Prestige" given its similarity with the plaintiff's registered mark.
* The plaintiff's sales turnover and advertising expenses are relevant evidence of its rights in the trade mark.
* The defendant's intention behind filing the trademark application, whether to deceive or ride on the plaintiff's goodwill.
* Whether there is any confusion among customers due to similar trade marks being used by different parties.
* Jurisdiction under Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) in applying for interim relief.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background:**

The case centers around a trademark dispute between TTK Prestige Ltd. (the plaintiff) and K K and Company Delhi Pvt. Ltd. (defendant no. 1), along with its sister concerns defendants no. 2 and 3.

**Legal Issues:**

The plaintiff has filed a lawsuit against the defendants, seeking a decree of permanent injunction and passing off under Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC). The primary legal issue revolves around protecting the trademark "PRESTIGE" registered in various classes for house marks since 1955 and preventing the defendant no. 1 from using a similar impugned trademark.

**Arguments:**

The plaintiff's arguments highlight the following points:

*   TTK Prestige Ltd. has been using the trademark "PRESTIGE" since 1955, with extensive registration in various classes.
*   The company has invested heavily in promoting its products under this brand name.
*   Defendant no. 1 filed a trademark application on November 2, 2018, for a device mark similar to the plaintiff's trademark. This act led to an opposition from TTK Prestige Ltd., which revealed that defendant no. 1 had been selling "gas stoves" under this logo in collaboration with defendants no. 2 and 3.
*   The impugned trademark was registered on January 1, 1981, but the company failed to use it continuously and without interruption until the filing of the suit.

**Court Findings:**

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (Amit Bansal, J) considered the following findings:

*   TTK Prestige Ltd.'s trademark "PRESTIGE" has been validly registered in various classes.
*   The company's sales turnover and advertising expenses demonstrate its genuine use of this brand name over time.
*   Defendant no. 1's trademark application was filed on November 2, 2018, which is considered bad faith due to the non-user of the mark.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 1 of 11 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
% 
 
 
 
 
Date of Decision : 20th February, 2023 
 
+  
 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022 
 
 
TTK PRESTIGE LTD 
 
 
 
 
..... Plaintiff 
Through: 
Mr.Hemant Singh, Ms.Mamta Rani 
Jha, 
Mr.Manish 
Kumar 
Mishra, 
Ms.Akansha 
Singh, 
Mr.Srinivas 
Venkat 
Rangan 
and 
Ms.Tarushi 
Agarwal, Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT  
LTD & ORS. 
 
 
 
 
 
..... Defendants 
Through: 
Mr.Sanjay Kumar, Advocate for D-1 
and D-2. 
Mr.Mukesh Thakur and Mr.Dhirendra 
Singh, Advocates for D-3. 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral) 
 
 
 
 
 
I.A. 20992/2022 (O-XXXIX R-1 & 2 of CPC) 
1. 
By way of the present judgment, I shall decide the application filed on 
behalf of the plaintiff under Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 of the Code of 
Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC). 
2. 
Briefly, the case set up in the plaint is that the plaintiff is engaged in 
the business of manufacturing, marketing and sale of kitchen home 
appliances, including „pressure cookers‟ and „gas stoves‟, both electric and 
non-electric, non-stick cookware, induction cook-tops, mixer grinders, 
chimneys etc., under the brand/trade mark „PRESTIGE‟ since 1955, which 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 2 of 11 
 
is a house mark of the plaintiff. All the plaintiff‟s products are sold under its 
house mark „PRESTIGE‟. 
3. 
Plaintiff also has several registrations of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
in various Classes, details of which are given in paragraph 7 of the plaint. 
The earliest registration of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) in 
Classes 8 and 21 dates back to 14th December, 1949. The trademark 
„PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) was registered in favour of the plaintiff in Class 
11 on 16th June, 1981 in respect of „installations for cooking‟ on a „proposed 
to be used basis‟. Subsequently, the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) 
was registered in favour of the plaintiff on 23rd September, 1999 specifically 
in respect of „gas stoves‟ on a „proposed to be used basis‟. All the aforesaid 
trademark registrations are valid and subsistent.  
4. 
The plaintiff has also filed its sales turnover in respect of its products 
under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ from the financial year 2007-08 to 2020-
21. The turnover of the plaintiff in the year 2007-08 was around 
Rs.339,00,00,000/-, whereas the turnover in the financial year 2020-21 was 
around Rs. 2,033,00,00,000. The plaintiff has also provided the advertising 
and promotional expenses incurred by plaintiff in respect of its trademark 
„PRESTIGE'. 
In 
the 
year 
2007-08, 
the 
plaintiff 
spent 
around 
Rs.24,00,00,000/- towards promotional expenses and in the year 2020-21 the 
plaintiff spent around Rs.98,00,00,000.  
5. 
The 
plaintiff 
operates 
websites, 
„http://www.ttkprestige.com/‟, 
„https://shop.ttkprestige.com/‟ and „http://www.prestigexclusive.in‟, which 
showcases the plaintiff‟s goods under the said mark. The plaintiff also has 
its presence on various e-commerce platforms. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 3 of 11 
 
6. 
The defendant no.1 is engaged in the business of manufacturing and 
sale of „gas stoves‟ and its component parts. It is averred in the plaint that 
the defendant no.2 and 3 are sister concerns of the defendant no.1.  
7. 
In the third week of August 2022, the plaintiff came across the 
trademark application dated 2nd November, 2018 filed on behalf of the 
defendant no.1 for the registration of the device mark 
 
(hereinafter referred to as 'impugned trademark'). The plaintiff opposed the 
registration of the aforesaid mark by filing opposition on 18th August, 2022. 
The plaintiff‟s trademark „PRESTIGE‟ in Class 11 was cited as a conflicting 
mark in the examination report of the Trade Marks Registry. Thereafter, the 
plaintiff carried out an investigation in which it was revealed that the 
defendant no.1 has been selling „gas stoves‟ in collusion with the defendants 
no.2 and 3 under the impugned trademark in bulk and on order basis only. 
8. 
Accordingly, the present suit was filed seeking a decree of permanent 
injunction, passing off along with other ancillary reliefs.  
9. 
The defence set up by the defendant no.1 in its written statement is 
that the said defendant no.1 has been using the impugned trademark since 1st 
January, 1981. The aforesaid date finds mention in the trademark 
registration application filed on behalf of the defendant no.1 on 1st 
November 2018. Therefore, it is claimed that the defendant no.1 is a prior 
user of the impugned trademark in respect of „gas stoves‟. The plaintiff filed 
its trademark application for the word mark „PRESTIGE‟ on 16th June, 1981 
on a „proposed to be used basis‟. The plaintiff was aware of the user of the 
trademark „PRESTIGE‟ by the defendant no.1 since 1981.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 4 of 11 
 
10. 
In order to show its prior user counsel for the defendant no.1 has 
placed reliance on: 
i. 
The certificate of registration granted in favour of the defendant no.1 
as a Small Scale Industries unit on 21st December, 1982. The 
application was filed on 16th August, 1980.  
ii. 
The classification list of excisable goods dated 8th May, 1985 granted 
in favour of the defendant no.1 wherein the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
has been mentioned.  
iii. 
The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) license granted in favour of the 
defendant no.1 on 22nd April, 1982 in respect of the brand name 
„PRESTIGE‟.  
11. 
Counsel appearing on behalf of the plaintiff makes the following 
submissions: 
i. 
Even though, the defendant no.1 claims to be the user of the 
impugned trademark from 1st January 1981, the earliest invoice filed 
by the defendant no.1 is of 29th March, 1982. The registration of the 
plaintiff‟s mark „PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) under Class 11 in respect 
of „installations for cooking‟ on a “proposed to be used basis” is of 
16th June, 1981, which is prior to the user of the impugned trademark 
in respect of „gas stoves‟ by the defendant no.1. Therefore, the 
defence under Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 (hereinafter 
referred to as „the Act‟) is not available to the defendant no.1.  
ii. 
Without prejudice to the aforesaid, the defendant no.1 has failed to 
make out a case of „continuous user‟ as envisaged under Section 34 of 
the Act. The defendant no.1 has placed on record only three invoices 
showing sales of goods bearing the impugned trademark, which are of 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 5 of 11 
 
the year 1982. Reliance in this regard is placed on the judgment of a 
Division Bench of this Court in Pioneer Nuts and Bolts Pvt. Ltd. v. 
Goodwill Enterprises, 2009 SCC OnLine Del 2851. 
iii. 
Counsel for the plaintiff has placed reliance on the various invoices 
showing sale of „gas stoves‟ by the plaintiff with effect from 20th 
September, 2007 (page no.260-300 of the plaintiff‟s document). 
Attention of the Court has been drawn to the advertisements taken out 
by the plaintiff in respect of gas stoves being sold under the trademark 
„PRESTIGE‟.  
iv. 
In view of the tremendous goodwill and reputation attained by the 
usage of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ in respect of „pressure cookers‟ 
as is evidenced by the sales turnover and promotional expenses, a case 
of passing off is also made out by the plaintiff. Reliance in this regard 
is placed on the judgment of United Brothers v. Navin Kumar, 2006 
SCC OnLine Del 185. 
12. 
I have heard the counsel for the parties.  
13. 
Though the defendant no.1 vehemently contends that it is a prior user 
of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ and has been continuously using the said 
trademark since the year 1981, the defendant no.1 has placed on record only 
three invoices, all of the year 1982 in support of his contention.  
14. 
A query was put to the counsel for the defendant no.1 that if the 
defendant no.1 has been continuously using the aforesaid trademark since 
1981, why has the defendant no.1 placed on record only three invoices. It 
was further put to the counsel for the defendant no.1 that whether any sales 
in respect of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ had been made in the last ten years.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 6 of 11 
 
15. 
Counsel for the defendant no.1 submits that he may be given further 
time so as to file documents to show the use of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
between the year 1981 till the current date.  
16. 
Under Sub-Rule 7 of Order XI Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 
1908 as applicable to commercial suits under the Commercial Courts Act, 
2015, a defendant has to file a list of all documents and photocopies of all 
documents, in its power, possession, control or custody, pertaining to the 
suit, along with the written statement. Sub-Rule 10 of Order XI Rule 1 of the 
CPC further provides that the defendant cannot be allowed to rely on 
documents, which were in the defendant‟s power, possession, control or 
custody and not disclosed along with the written statement, except with the 
leave of Court.  
17. 
What emerges form a reading of the aforesaid provisions is that along 
with the written statement the defendant has to file all documents in his 
power and possession and in support of his case. Additional documents can 
be filed only with a leave of the Court and upon the defendant giving a 
reasonable explanation for not filing the same with the written statement. 
Admittedly, no such application has been filed on behalf of the defendant 
no.1 seeking leave to file additional documents.  Therefore, no further time 
can be granted to the defendant no.1 to place additional documents on 
record. As the defendant no.1 claims to be „continuous user‟ of the 
trademark „PRESTIGE‟ from 1981, it should have filed documents 
evidencing such „continuous user‟. In the absence of any documents, the 
Court shall presume that there was no „continuous user‟ by the defendant 
no.1. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 7 of 11 
 
18. 
In this regard reference may be made to the judgment of a Division 
Bench of this Court in Pioneer Nuts (supra). In Pioneer Nuts (supra) relying 
upon the earlier judgments in Amaravathi Enterprises v. Karaikudi 
Chettinadu, 2008 (36) PTC 688 (Madras)(DB) and in Veerumal Praveen 
Kumar v. Needle Industries (India) Pvt. Ltd., 2001 (21) PTC 668 (Delhi), 
the Division Bench has observed that a trader has to show that in relation to 
particular goods, there is a goodwill connecting the trader with the goods on 
account of the use of trademark. Holding that the defendant in the said case 
had failed to place evidence on record to show that it had actually sold its 
goods using the impugned marks other than two newspaper advertisements 
and a few trade enquiries, the Division Bench was pleased to grant interim 
injunction in favour of the plaintiff. It was further observed that mere filing 
of a trademark application and giving an arbitrary date of user would not in 
itself constitute evidence of use from the said date.  
19. 
The aforesaid dicta is fully applicable to the facts of the present case. 
In the present case, the trademark application has been filed on behalf of the 
defendant no.1 only on 2nd November, 2018 claiming user from 1st January, 
1981. Other than three invoices of the year 1982 and few statutory 
registrations in favour of the defendant no.1, no credible evidence in the 
form of invoices or advertisements or other material has been filed to show 
that the defendant no.1 has been continuously using the impugned trademark 
so as to constitute any goodwill or reputation in its favour. Accordingly, I 
am of the view that the defendant no.1 has at best shown sporadic use of the 
impugned trademark, which would not qualify it as a „continuous user‟ in 
terms of section 34 of the Act.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 8 of 11 
 
20. 
Counsel for the defendant no.1 vehemently contends that the 
trademark application filed on behalf of the plaintiff is on a „proposed to be 
used‟ basis and the plaintiff has not filed any documents to show their user. 
To claim the defence of section 34 of the Act, defendant no.1 has to show its 
continuous user prior to (a) user of the plaintiff or (b) date of registration in 
favour of the plaintiff in respect of the said goods, whichever is earlier.  
21. 
In the present case, the date of registration in favour of the plaintiff in 
respect of „installations for cooking‟ is of 16th June, 1981, which is the 
earlier date. The phrase „installations for cooking‟ would cover within its 
scope 'gas stoves‟. Three invoices filed on behalf of the defendant no.1 are 
admittedly of a subsequent date. Defendant no.1 has also placed reliance on 
the Small Scale Industries (SSI) certificate dated 21st December, 1982, BIS 
license dated 24th April, 1982 as well as excise documents dated 8th May, 
1985 in support of his submission that the defendant no.1 is a prior user of 
the trademark „PRESTIGE‟. The SSI certificate in favour of the defendant 
no.1 does not mention the trademark „PRESTIGE‟. Both the BIS license as 
well as excise documents are after the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ of the 
plaintiff was registered in Class 11. Therefore, the defendant no.1 has failed 
to establish use of the impugned trademark prior to the registration granted 
in favour of the plaintiff. Admittedly, no defence has been taken in the 
written statement with regard to validity of the registration granted in favour 
of the plaintiff.  
22. 
On the basis of the sales turnover as well as the promotional expenses 
placed on record by the plaintiff, the plaintiff has also established, at a prima 
facie stage, immense goodwill and reputation of its trademark „PRESTIGE‟, 
albeit in respect of „pressure cookers‟. The plaintiff has been selling its 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 9 of 11 
 
products under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ since 1955 and the earliest 
registration of the plaintiff‟s mark is of 14th December, 1949. Further, the 
plaintiff has placed on record various invoices from the year 2007 to show 
sales of „gas stoves‟ and advertisements of the year 2019 to show that it was 
in the business of selling „gas stoves‟ under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟. 
Even the defendant no.1 does not dispute the position that the plaintiff has 
been selling „pressure cookers‟ under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ much 
before the defendant no.1. The only defence put forth by the defendant no.1 
is that „pressure cookers‟ and „gas stoves‟ are different products and 
therefore, there would be no confusion in the market.  
23. 
In this regard, counsel for the plaintiff has correctly placed reliance on 
the judgment of a Co-ordinate Bench of this Court in United Brothers 
(supra), which dealt with the passing off claim in respect of the same 
products that are subject matter of the present suit viz. „LPG stoves‟ and 
„pressure cookers‟ being sold under the same trademark, „United‟. While 
granting injunction in favour of the plaintiff, the Co-ordinate Bench 
observed that the goods of the plaintiff as well as the defendants are both 
used as kitchen appliances and therefore, there would be confusion for the 
consumer using both the products. Further, in view of the sales turnover as 
well as advertising expenses filed by the plaintiff, the plaintiff was able to 
establish that its trademark had acquired distinctiveness and goodwill in the 
market. Accordingly, it was observed that confusion is likely to be caused in 
the mind of public and hence,  the interim injunction granted in favour of the 
plaintiff was confirmed.  
24. 
The aforesaid judgment is clearly applicable to the facts and 
circumstances of the present case as the two goods in question in the said 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 10 of 11 
 
case and case at hand are identical. The use of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
by the defendant no.1 in respect of „gas stoves‟ is likely to cause confusion 
in the market as the public at large would associate the said products of the 
defendant no.1 with the plaintiff.  
25. 
In view of the discussion above, a prima facie case of infringement as 
well as passing off is made out on behalf of the plaintiff. Balance of 
convenience is also in favour of plaintiff and against the defendant no.1. The 
plaintiff shall continue to suffer irreparable injury to its goodwill and 
reputation if the defendant no.1 is permitted to manufacture and sell goods 
bearing the impugned trademark. 
26. 
Accordingly, the present application is allowed and the defendant 
no.1, its directors, sister concerns, assigns in business, distributors, stockists, 
dealers and agents are injuncted from manufacturing, selling, offering for 
sale, exporting, advertising in any manner including on the internet and 
websites, directly or indirectly dealing in gas stoves or in any kitchenware, 
cookware and/or cognate/allied/related goods under the mark 
 
or any other mark which is identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff‟s 
„PRESTIGE‟ trademarks. 
CS(COMM) 864/2022 
27. 
Counsels for the defendants no.2 and 3 submit that they are not the 
sister concerns of the defendant no.1 and do not manufacture or sell any 
product using the impugned trademark. 
28. 
Hence, without going into the merits, the defendants no.2 and 3 have 
no objection if a decree of permanent injunction is passed against them 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 11 ---
 
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 11 of 11 
 
restraining them from using the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ or any other mark 
which is identical or deceptively similar to that of the plaintiff. 
29. 
Accordingly, the suit is decreed against the defendants no.2 and 3 in 
terms of prayer clauses (i) and (ii) of the plaint.  
30. 
Counsel for the plaintiff does not press for reliefs sought in prayer 
clauses (iii), (iv), (v), (vi) and (vii) against the defendants no.2 and 3.  
31. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up. 
32. 
The suit shall continue to proceed against the defendant no.1. 
33. 
List before the Joint Registrar on 3rd May, 2023 for further 
proceedings. 
I.A. 1139/2023 (O-I R-10 of CPC) and I.A. 2624/2023 (O-I R-10 of CPC) 
34. 
 In view of the above, the present applications have become 
infructuous and are disposed of as such. 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J 
FEBRUARY 20, 2023 
sr 
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
The document is a court judgment from the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi in the case of TTK Prestige Ltd vs K K And Company Delhi Pvt. Ltd & Ors (2023/DHC/001280).

**Case Details:**

* Case number: CS(COMM) 864/2022
* Date of decision: 20th February, 2023
* Presiding judge: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL

**Parties:**

* Plaintiff: TTK Prestige Ltd
	+ Represented by: Mr. Hemant Singh, Ms. Mamta Rani Jha, Mr. Manish Kumar Mishra, Ms. Akansha Singh, Mr. Srinivas Venkat Rangan, and Ms. Tarushi Agarwal, Advocates
* Defendants:
	+ K K And Company Delhi Pvt. Ltd (D-1)
		- Represented by: Mr. Sanjay Kumar, Advocate
	+ Ors. (Defendants 2 and 3)

**Facts and Arguments:**

* TTK Prestige Ltd has been manufacturing kitchen home appliances under the brand/trade mark "PRESTIGE" since 1955.
* The plaintiff has several trademark registrations for "PRESTIGE" in various classes, with the earliest registration dating back to 1949.
* The plaintiff claims that it operates websites and e-commerce platforms showcasing its goods under the said mark.

**Decision:**

* The court will decide on an application filed by the plaintiff under Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC).

**Amounts MENTIONED:**

* Plaintiff's sales turnover:
	+ Rs.339,00,00,000/- in financial year 2007-08
	+ Rs. 2,033,00,00,000/- in financial year 2020-21

..... Plaintiff

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 2 from PDF: "20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf"

**Background**

The plaintiff, TTK Prestige Ltd., has a long-standing trademark registration for "PRESTIGE" in various classes.

**Trademark Registration**

* The trademark "PRESTIGE" was registered on 14th December, 1949, in Classes 8 and 21.
* It was later registered in Class 11 on 16th June, 1981, specifically for "installations for cooking".
* Another registration was made on 23rd September, 1999, in respect of "gas stoves".

**Sales Turnover**

* The plaintiff's sales turnover under the trademark "PRESTIGE" increased from Rs.339,00,00,000/- (2007-08) to Rs.2,033,00,00,000/- (2020-21).
* Advertising and promotional expenses also increased from Rs.24,00,00,000/- (2007-08) to Rs.98,00,00,000/- (2020-21).

Source: PDF "20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf"
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280

is a house mark of the plaintiff. All the plaintiff‟s products are sold under its 
house mark „PRESTIGE‟. 
3. 
Plaintiff also has several registrations of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
in various Classes, details of which are given in paragraph 7 of the plaint. 
The earliest registration of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) in 
Classes 8 and 21 dates back to 14th December, 1949. The trademark 
„PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) was registered in favour of the plaintiff in Class 
11 on 16th June, 1981 in respect of „installations for cooking‟ on a „proposed 
to be used basis‟. Subsequently, the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) 
was registered in favour of the plaintiff on 23rd September, 1999 specifically 
in respect of „gas stoves‟ on a „proposed to be used basis‟. All the aforesaid 
trademark registrations are valid and subsistent.  
4. 
The plaintiff has also filed its sales turnover in respect of its products 
under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ from the financial year 2007-08 to 2020-
21. The turnover of the plaintiff in the year 2007-08 was around 
Rs.339,00,00,000/-, whereas the turnover in the financial year 2020-21 was 
around Rs. 2,033,00,00,000. The plaintiff has also provided the advertising 
and promotional expenses incurred by plaintiff in respect of its trademark 
„PRESTIGE'. 
In 
the 
year 
2007-08, 
the 
plaintiff 
spent 
around 
Rs.24,00,00,000/- towards promotional expenses and in the year 2020-21 the 
plaintiff spent around Rs.98,00,00,000.  
5. 
The 
plaintiff 
operates 
websites, 
„http://www.ttkprestige.com/‟, 
„https://shop.ttkprestige.com/‟ and „http://www.prestigexclusive.in‟, which 
showcases the plaintiff‟s goods under the said mark. The plaintiff also has 
its presence on various e-commerce platforms.

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary: TTK Prestige Ltd vs K K And Company Delhi Pvt (2023/DHC/001280)**

* **Citation:** CS(COMM) 864/2022
* **Date of Decision:** February 20, 2023
* **Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Background and Facts:**

TTK Prestige Ltd. filed a lawsuit against K K And Company Delhi Pvt. over trademark infringement.

* The plaintiff's trademark "PRESTIGE" was opposed by the defendant due to alleged similarity with their trademark application for the device mark (impugned trademark).
* The plaintiff alleged that the defendants were using the impugned trademark in collusion, selling gas stoves under this mark.
* The defendants claimed prior user of the impugned trademark since January 1, 1981.

**Arguments and Submissions:**

* Defendant No. 1 relied on:
	+ Registration as a Small Scale Industries unit (December 21, 1982)
	+ Classification list of excisable goods (May 8, 1985)
	+ Bureau of Indian Standards license (April 22, 1982)
* Plaintiff argued that the defendant's earliest invoice is dated March 29, 1982, and their trademark registration was filed on June 16, 1981.
* The plaintiff also claimed that the defendant failed to establish continuous user under Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act.

**Decision Not Mentioned in Details**

(No specific details about the decision are mentioned. The content seems truncated.)

**PDF Source:** 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the provided PDF:

**Case Details:** TTK Prestige Ltd vs. K K And Company Delhi Pvt. (2022)

**Legal Facts:**

* Defendant no.1 manufactures and sells gas stoves.
* Defendants nos. 2 & 3 are sister concerns to defendant no.1.

**Proceedings:**

* Plaintiff opposed the registration of "gas stove" trademark by defendant no.1 due to conflict with their existing trademark "PRESTIGE".
* Plaintiff conducted an investigation revealing that defendant no.1 sold gas stoves under the impugned trademark in bulk and on order basis.
* Suit filed seeking permanent injunction, passing off alongside other reliefs.

**Defense:**

* Defendant no.1 claims usage of the impugned trademark since January 1981, prior to plaintiff's application.
* Plaintiff's trademark "PRESTIGE" was applied for in June 1981 on a proposed-to-be-used basis.

**Note:** This is based on information from page 3 of the PDF source: "20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf".
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 3 of 11 
 
6. 
The defendant no.1 is engaged in the business of manufacturing and 
sale of „gas stoves‟ and its component parts. It is averred in the plaint that 
the defendant no.2 and 3 are sister concerns of the defendant no.1.  
7. 
In the third week of August 2022, the plaintiff came across the 
trademark application dated 2nd November, 2018 filed on behalf of the 
defendant no.1 for the registration of the device mark 
 
(hereinafter referred to as 'impugned trademark'). The plaintiff opposed the 
registration of the aforesaid mark by filing opposition on 18th August, 2022. 
The plaintiff‟s trademark „PRESTIGE‟ in Class 11 was cited as a conflicting 
mark in the examination report of the Trade Marks Registry. Thereafter, the 
plaintiff carried out an investigation in which it was revealed that the 
defendant no.1 has been selling „gas stoves‟ in collusion with the defendants 
no.2 and 3 under the impugned trademark in bulk and on order basis only. 
8. 
Accordingly, the present suit was filed seeking a decree of permanent 
injunction, passing off along with other ancillary reliefs.  
9. 
The defence set up by the defendant no.1 in its written statement is 
that the said defendant no.1 has been using the impugned trademark since 1st 
January, 1981. The aforesaid date finds mention in the trademark 
registration application filed on behalf of the defendant no.1 on 1st 
November 2018. Therefore, it is claimed that the defendant no.1 is a prior 
user of the impugned trademark in respect of „gas stoves‟. The plaintiff filed 
its trademark application for the word mark „PRESTIGE‟ on 16th June, 1981 
on a „proposed to be used basis‟. The plaintiff was aware of the user of the 
trademark „PRESTIGE‟ by the defendant no.1 since 1981.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 4 from PDF: TTK Prestige Ltd vs K K And Company Delhi Pvt**

The plaintiff's counsel argues that defendant no.1 (K K And Company) cannot claim prior user status despite being registered as a Small Scale Industries unit in 1982 and obtaining a Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) license in 1982.

However, the plaintiff submits:

* The earliest invoice by defendant no.1 is dated March 29, 1982, while the plaintiff's trademark registration for "PRESTIGE" under Class 11 for cooking installations was proposed on June 16, 1981.
* Defendant no.1 has failed to make a case of continuous user as required under Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, citing only three invoices.

Source:  Page 4 from PDF: **20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT**

**Case Details**: CS(COMM) 864/2022; High Court of Delhi at New Delhi; Date of Decision: February 20, 2023
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 4 of 11 
 
10. 
In order to show its prior user counsel for the defendant no.1 has 
placed reliance on: 
i. 
The certificate of registration granted in favour of the defendant no.1 
as a Small Scale Industries unit on 21st December, 1982. The 
application was filed on 16th August, 1980.  
ii. 
The classification list of excisable goods dated 8th May, 1985 granted 
in favour of the defendant no.1 wherein the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
has been mentioned.  
iii. 
The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) license granted in favour of the 
defendant no.1 on 22nd April, 1982 in respect of the brand name 
„PRESTIGE‟.  
11. 
Counsel appearing on behalf of the plaintiff makes the following 
submissions: 
i. 
Even though, the defendant no.1 claims to be the user of the 
impugned trademark from 1st January 1981, the earliest invoice filed 
by the defendant no.1 is of 29th March, 1982. The registration of the 
plaintiff‟s mark „PRESTIGE‟ (word per se) under Class 11 in respect 
of „installations for cooking‟ on a “proposed to be used basis” is of 
16th June, 1981, which is prior to the user of the impugned trademark 
in respect of „gas stoves‟ by the defendant no.1. Therefore, the 
defence under Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 (hereinafter 
referred to as „the Act‟) is not available to the defendant no.1.  
ii. 
Without prejudice to the aforesaid, the defendant no.1 has failed to 
make out a case of „continuous user‟ as envisaged under Section 34 of 
the Act. The defendant no.1 has placed on record only three invoices 
showing sales of goods bearing the impugned trademark, which are of 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Here's a summary of page 5 from the PDF:

The court discusses the plaintiff's case against the defendant for trademark infringement. The counsel for the plaintiff relies on the following points:

* A Division Bench judgment in Pioneer Nuts and Bolts Pvt. Ltd v. Goodwill Enterprises (2009) to establish that the plaintiff has a prior trademark right in "Prestige".
* Invoices showing sale of gas stoves by the plaintiff with effect from September 20, 2007.
* Advertisements taken out by the plaintiff for selling gas stoves under the trademark "Prestige".

The court also notes that:

* The defendant's counsel claims that the defendant is a prior user of the trademark "PRESTIGE" since 1981 but only provides three invoices from 1982 to support this claim.
* A query was put to the defendant's counsel why only three invoices were provided and whether any sales were made with the "Prestige" trademark in the last ten years.

Document source: [case number] CS(COMM) 864/2022, TTK Prestige Ltd v. K K And Company Delhi Pvt. (PDF hosted online).
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 5 of 11 
 
the year 1982. Reliance in this regard is placed on the judgment of a 
Division Bench of this Court in Pioneer Nuts and Bolts Pvt. Ltd. v. 
Goodwill Enterprises, 2009 SCC OnLine Del 2851. 
iii. 
Counsel for the plaintiff has placed reliance on the various invoices 
showing sale of „gas stoves‟ by the plaintiff with effect from 20th 
September, 2007 (page no.260-300 of the plaintiff‟s document). 
Attention of the Court has been drawn to the advertisements taken out 
by the plaintiff in respect of gas stoves being sold under the trademark 
„PRESTIGE‟.  
iv. 
In view of the tremendous goodwill and reputation attained by the 
usage of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ in respect of „pressure cookers‟ 
as is evidenced by the sales turnover and promotional expenses, a case 
of passing off is also made out by the plaintiff. Reliance in this regard 
is placed on the judgment of United Brothers v. Navin Kumar, 2006 
SCC OnLine Del 185. 
12. 
I have heard the counsel for the parties.  
13. 
Though the defendant no.1 vehemently contends that it is a prior user 
of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ and has been continuously using the said 
trademark since the year 1981, the defendant no.1 has placed on record only 
three invoices, all of the year 1982 in support of his contention.  
14. 
A query was put to the counsel for the defendant no.1 that if the 
defendant no.1 has been continuously using the aforesaid trademark since 
1981, why has the defendant no.1 placed on record only three invoices. It 
was further put to the counsel for the defendant no.1 that whether any sales 
in respect of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ had been made in the last ten years.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Case:** TTK Prestige Ltd vs. K K And Company Delhi Pvt

**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Citation:** CS(COMM) 864/2022

The document outlines a legal dispute between TTK Prestige Ltd (plaintiff) and K K And Company Delhi Pvt (defendant) over trademark rights.

**Key Facts:**

* Defendant seeks additional time to submit documents showing continuous use of the mark "PRESTIGE" from 1981.
* Plaintiff's counsel argue that defendant failed to provide all required documents with their written statement, as per Order XI Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure (CPC).
* Defendant claims continuous user since 1981 but lacks credible evidence, such as invoices or advertisements.

**Arguments and Decisions:**

* Court refuses to grant additional time for defendant to submit more documentation.
* Plaintiff's arguments rely on Section 34 of the Trademarks Act, which requires proof of goodwill and reputation through continuous use.
* Court cites earlier judgments (Pioneer Nuts and Amaravathi Enterprises) emphasizing the need for credible evidence to establish trademark rights.

**Result:**

* Defendant's claim to "continuous user" is deemed baseless without sufficient evidence.
* Interim order likely in favor of plaintiff (TTK Prestige Ltd).

Source: Section from PDF: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 6 from PDF:**

Source: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf (CS(COMM) 864/2022)

**Key Points:**

* Defendant No.1's counsel seeks additional time to file documents showing use of trademark "PRESTIGE" between 1981 and the current date.
* Sub-Rule 7 of Order XI Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) requires defendants to file a list of all relevant documents with their written statement.
* Sub-Rule 10 of Order XI Rule 1 CPC prohibits defendants from relying on undisclosed documents without Court permission.
* No application was filed by Defendant No.1 to seek leave to file additional documents.
* As no supporting documents were filed, the court will presume there was no "continuous user" by Defendant No.1.

**Dates and Names:**

* February 20th, 2023 (Date of Decision)
* Amit Bansal (DHF Signature)

**PDF Source:** 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 6 of 11 
 
15. 
Counsel for the defendant no.1 submits that he may be given further 
time so as to file documents to show the use of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
between the year 1981 till the current date.  
16. 
Under Sub-Rule 7 of Order XI Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 
1908 as applicable to commercial suits under the Commercial Courts Act, 
2015, a defendant has to file a list of all documents and photocopies of all 
documents, in its power, possession, control or custody, pertaining to the 
suit, along with the written statement. Sub-Rule 10 of Order XI Rule 1 of the 
CPC further provides that the defendant cannot be allowed to rely on 
documents, which were in the defendant‟s power, possession, control or 
custody and not disclosed along with the written statement, except with the 
leave of Court.  
17. 
What emerges form a reading of the aforesaid provisions is that along 
with the written statement the defendant has to file all documents in his 
power and possession and in support of his case. Additional documents can 
be filed only with a leave of the Court and upon the defendant giving a 
reasonable explanation for not filing the same with the written statement. 
Admittedly, no such application has been filed on behalf of the defendant 
no.1 seeking leave to file additional documents.  Therefore, no further time 
can be granted to the defendant no.1 to place additional documents on 
record. As the defendant no.1 claims to be „continuous user‟ of the 
trademark „PRESTIGE‟ from 1981, it should have filed documents 
evidencing such „continuous user‟. In the absence of any documents, the 
Court shall presume that there was no „continuous user‟ by the defendant 
no.1. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 7 from the PDF document:

**Case Details:**

* Case No.: CS(COMM) 864/2022
* Plaintiff: TTK Prestige Ltd., represented by Mr. Hemant Singh, Ms. Mamta Rani Jha, etc.
* Defendant: K K And Company Delhi Pvt. Ltd.

**Judgment Summary:**

The court refers to a Division Bench judgment in Pioneer Nuts (supra) and holds that the defendant has failed to provide credible evidence of continuous use of the trademark. The defendant had filed a trademark application claiming user from 1981, but only presented three invoices from 1982 and few statutory registrations. This is considered sporadic use, not qualifying as a "continuous user" under Section 34 of the Act.

**Key Dates:**

* 2nd November, 2018: Defendant No. 1 filed trademark application
* 20th February, 2023: Judgment Date

**Source:** PDF document titled "20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT"
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 7 of 11 
 
18. 
In this regard reference may be made to the judgment of a Division 
Bench of this Court in Pioneer Nuts (supra). In Pioneer Nuts (supra) relying 
upon the earlier judgments in Amaravathi Enterprises v. Karaikudi 
Chettinadu, 2008 (36) PTC 688 (Madras)(DB) and in Veerumal Praveen 
Kumar v. Needle Industries (India) Pvt. Ltd., 2001 (21) PTC 668 (Delhi), 
the Division Bench has observed that a trader has to show that in relation to 
particular goods, there is a goodwill connecting the trader with the goods on 
account of the use of trademark. Holding that the defendant in the said case 
had failed to place evidence on record to show that it had actually sold its 
goods using the impugned marks other than two newspaper advertisements 
and a few trade enquiries, the Division Bench was pleased to grant interim 
injunction in favour of the plaintiff. It was further observed that mere filing 
of a trademark application and giving an arbitrary date of user would not in 
itself constitute evidence of use from the said date.  
19. 
The aforesaid dicta is fully applicable to the facts of the present case. 
In the present case, the trademark application has been filed on behalf of the 
defendant no.1 only on 2nd November, 2018 claiming user from 1st January, 
1981. Other than three invoices of the year 1982 and few statutory 
registrations in favour of the defendant no.1, no credible evidence in the 
form of invoices or advertisements or other material has been filed to show 
that the defendant no.1 has been continuously using the impugned trademark 
so as to constitute any goodwill or reputation in its favour. Accordingly, I 
am of the view that the defendant no.1 has at best shown sporadic use of the 
impugned trademark, which would not qualify it as a „continuous user‟ in 
terms of section 34 of the Act.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 from PDF: "20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf":

**Key Points**

1. Defendant no.1's counsel argues that plaintiff's trademark application is on a "proposed to be used" basis and lacks documents showing user.
2. To claim section 34 defense, defendant must show continuous user prior to (a) plaintiff's user or (b) registration date in favor of the plaintiff.
3. Plaintiff's trademark was registered on June 16, 1981, making it the earlier date.
4. Defendant presented invoices, SSI certificate, BIS license, and excise documents dated after the plaintiff's trademark was registered.
5. These documents do not establish prior use of the impugned trademark "PRESTIGE".
6. Plaintiff has established prima facie goodwill and reputation for its trademark "PRESTIGE" through sales turnover and promotional expenses.

**Important Dates**

* June 16, 1981: Plaintiff's trademark registration date
* December 21, 1982: Defendant's SSI certificate (without mention of the trademark)
* April 24, 1982: BIS license for defendant (after plaintiff's registration)
* May 8, 1985: Excise documents for defendant (after plaintiff's registration)

**Important Names**

* Plaintiff: TTK PRESTIGE LTD
* Defendant no.1:
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 8 of 11 
 
20. 
Counsel for the defendant no.1 vehemently contends that the 
trademark application filed on behalf of the plaintiff is on a „proposed to be 
used‟ basis and the plaintiff has not filed any documents to show their user. 
To claim the defence of section 34 of the Act, defendant no.1 has to show its 
continuous user prior to (a) user of the plaintiff or (b) date of registration in 
favour of the plaintiff in respect of the said goods, whichever is earlier.  
21. 
In the present case, the date of registration in favour of the plaintiff in 
respect of „installations for cooking‟ is of 16th June, 1981, which is the 
earlier date. The phrase „installations for cooking‟ would cover within its 
scope 'gas stoves‟. Three invoices filed on behalf of the defendant no.1 are 
admittedly of a subsequent date. Defendant no.1 has also placed reliance on 
the Small Scale Industries (SSI) certificate dated 21st December, 1982, BIS 
license dated 24th April, 1982 as well as excise documents dated 8th May, 
1985 in support of his submission that the defendant no.1 is a prior user of 
the trademark „PRESTIGE‟. The SSI certificate in favour of the defendant 
no.1 does not mention the trademark „PRESTIGE‟. Both the BIS license as 
well as excise documents are after the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ of the 
plaintiff was registered in Class 11. Therefore, the defendant no.1 has failed 
to establish use of the impugned trademark prior to the registration granted 
in favour of the plaintiff. Admittedly, no defence has been taken in the 
written statement with regard to validity of the registration granted in favour 
of the plaintiff.  
22. 
On the basis of the sales turnover as well as the promotional expenses 
placed on record by the plaintiff, the plaintiff has also established, at a prima 
facie stage, immense goodwill and reputation of its trademark „PRESTIGE‟, 
albeit in respect of „pressure cookers‟. The plaintiff has been selling its 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 9 from PDF 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT (2023/DHC/001280):

The plaintiff, TTK Prestige Ltd, has been selling products under the trademark "PRESTIGE" since 1955, with an earliest registration date of December 14, 1949. The plaintiff has submitted invoices from 2007 to show sales of "gas stoves" and advertisements from 2019 to demonstrate its business in selling "gas stoves" under the trademark "PRESTIGE". The defendant no.1 does not dispute that the plaintiff was selling "pressure cookers" under the same trademark before them.

The defense argued by defendant no.1 is that "pressure cookers" and "gas stoves" are different products, making confusion unlikely in the market. However, the plaintiff's counsel relies on a Co-ordinate Bench judgment (United Brothers) where the court granted an injunction in favor of the plaintiff due to customer confusion between similar kitchen appliances sold under the same trademark "United".

The Co-ordinate Bench observation is applicable to this case, as both goods are used as kitchen appliances, likely causing confusion among customers. The judgment supports granting an interim injunction in favor of the plaintiff.

Source: PDF 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT (2023/DHC/001280) - CS
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 9 of 11 
 
products under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ since 1955 and the earliest 
registration of the plaintiff‟s mark is of 14th December, 1949. Further, the 
plaintiff has placed on record various invoices from the year 2007 to show 
sales of „gas stoves‟ and advertisements of the year 2019 to show that it was 
in the business of selling „gas stoves‟ under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟. 
Even the defendant no.1 does not dispute the position that the plaintiff has 
been selling „pressure cookers‟ under the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ much 
before the defendant no.1. The only defence put forth by the defendant no.1 
is that „pressure cookers‟ and „gas stoves‟ are different products and 
therefore, there would be no confusion in the market.  
23. 
In this regard, counsel for the plaintiff has correctly placed reliance on 
the judgment of a Co-ordinate Bench of this Court in United Brothers 
(supra), which dealt with the passing off claim in respect of the same 
products that are subject matter of the present suit viz. „LPG stoves‟ and 
„pressure cookers‟ being sold under the same trademark, „United‟. While 
granting injunction in favour of the plaintiff, the Co-ordinate Bench 
observed that the goods of the plaintiff as well as the defendants are both 
used as kitchen appliances and therefore, there would be confusion for the 
consumer using both the products. Further, in view of the sales turnover as 
well as advertising expenses filed by the plaintiff, the plaintiff was able to 
establish that its trademark had acquired distinctiveness and goodwill in the 
market. Accordingly, it was observed that confusion is likely to be caused in 
the mind of public and hence,  the interim injunction granted in favour of the 
plaintiff was confirmed.  
24. 
The aforesaid judgment is clearly applicable to the facts and 
circumstances of the present case as the two goods in question in the said 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary**

**PDF Source:** TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT (2023/DHC/001280)

**Court Decision:**

On February 20, 2023, the Delhi High Court delivered a judgment in the case of TTK Prestige Ltd. vs. K K and Company Delhi Pvt.

**Facts and Arguments:**

* The plaintiff, TTK Prestige Ltd., alleged that the defendant no.1 (K K and Company Delhi Pvt.) was using its trademark "PRESTIGE" for gas stoves, causing confusion among consumers.
* The plaintiff claimed a prima facie case of infringement and passing off, and argued that they would suffer irreparable injury to their goodwill and reputation if the defendant continued to use the impugned trademark.

**Decision:**

* The Court held that the defendant no.1's use of the trademark "PRESTIGE" for gas stoves was likely to cause confusion among consumers.
* The plaintiff was granted a permanent injunction against the defendant no.1, restraining them from manufacturing, selling, or advertising goods bearing the impugned trademark.
* The Court also decreed the suit in favor of the plaintiff against defendants no.2 and 3, who were not found to be sister concerns of defendant no.1.

**Parties:**

* Plaintiff: TTK Prestige Ltd.
* Defendants:
	+ No.1: K K and Company Delhi Pvt.
	+ No.2: unknown
	+ No.3: unknown

**Dates:**

* Date of decision: February 20, 2023
* Date for further proceedings: May 3, 2023
tree_structure.pdf_source: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf

nodes.title: Page 10
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 10 from PDF: 20. TTK Prestige Ltd Vs. K K And Company Delhi Pvt**

**Case No:** CS(COMM) 864/2022
**Order Date:** February 20, 2023
**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

The court finds that the case and case at hand are identical (Page 10). **Arguments in favour of plaintiff:**

* The defendant no.1's use of the trademark "PRESTIGE" for gas stoves can cause market confusion.
* Public would associate defendant's products with the plaintiff.

**Decision:**

* Plaintiff has made out a prima facie case of infringement and passing off.
* Balance of convenience is in favour of the plaintiff.
* Defendant no.1, its directors, sister concerns, assigns, distributors, stockists, dealers, and agents are **injuncted from using or dealing with similar marks**(Page 11).

Sources:
 Page 10 of CS(COMM) 864/2022 | PDF: 20. TTK PRESTIGE LTD Vs. K K AND COMPANY DELHI PVT.pdf
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001280 
 
 
CS(COMM) 864/2022                                                                                             Page 10 of 11 
 
case and case at hand are identical. The use of the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ 
by the defendant no.1 in respect of „gas stoves‟ is likely to cause confusion 
in the market as the public at large would associate the said products of the 
defendant no.1 with the plaintiff.  
25. 
In view of the discussion above, a prima facie case of infringement as 
well as passing off is made out on behalf of the plaintiff. Balance of 
convenience is also in favour of plaintiff and against the defendant no.1. The 
plaintiff shall continue to suffer irreparable injury to its goodwill and 
reputation if the defendant no.1 is permitted to manufacture and sell goods 
bearing the impugned trademark. 
26. 
Accordingly, the present application is allowed and the defendant 
no.1, its directors, sister concerns, assigns in business, distributors, stockists, 
dealers and agents are injuncted from manufacturing, selling, offering for 
sale, exporting, advertising in any manner including on the internet and 
websites, directly or indirectly dealing in gas stoves or in any kitchenware, 
cookware and/or cognate/allied/related goods under the mark 
 
or any other mark which is identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff‟s 
„PRESTIGE‟ trademarks. 
CS(COMM) 864/2022 
27. 
Counsels for the defendants no.2 and 3 submit that they are not the 
sister concerns of the defendant no.1 and do not manufacture or sell any 
product using the impugned trademark. 
28. 
Hence, without going into the merits, the defendants no.2 and 3 have 
no objection if a decree of permanent injunction is passed against them 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.02.2023 11:11:22
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 11
nodes.summary:
Here's a summary of page 11 from the provided PDF:

**Case Details:**

* Case Number: CS(COMM) 864/2022
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Date of Decision: February 20, 2023
* DHC File No.: 2023/DHC/001280

**Decree:**

* The court decrees the suit against defendants no. 2 and 3 in terms of prayer clauses (i) and (ii) of the plaint.
* The plaintiff is restrained from using the trademark "PRESTIGE" or any other mark identical or deceptively similar to that of the plaintiff.

**Further Proceedings:**

* Counsel for the plaintiff does not press for reliefs sought in prayer clauses (iii) to (vii).
* The suit shall continue to proceed against defendant no. 1.
* List before the Joint Registrar on May 3, 2023, for further proceedings.

**Source:** TTK Prestige Ltd vs K K and Company Delhi Pvt: IN THE HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI. (PDF sourced from online database)

restraining them from using the trademark „PRESTIGE‟ or any other mark 
which is identical or deceptively similar to that of the plaintiff. 
29. 
Accordingly, the suit is decreed against the defendants no.2 and 3 in 
terms of prayer clauses (i) and (ii) of the plaint.  
30. 
Counsel for the plaintiff does not press for reliefs sought in prayer 
clauses (iii), (iv), (v), (vi) and (vii) against the defendants no.2 and 3.  
31. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up. 
32. 
The suit shall continue to proceed against the defendant no.1. 
33. 
List before the Joint Registrar on 3rd May, 2023 for further 
proceedings. 
I.A. 1139/2023 (O-I R-10 of CPC) and I.A. 2624/2023 (O-I R-10 of CPC) 
34. 
 In view of the above, the present applications have become 
infructuous and are disposed of as such. 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J 
FEBRUARY 20, 2023
